docs.lead_paragraph: Not too many years ago, this town of fewer than 4,000 people in the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains was a sleepy farming community with two stop lights. Now, Pigeon Forge and the equally tiny town of Gatlinburg, just five miles away, are each overrun by as many as 100,000 people on a summer's day -- a total of 10 million visitors each throughout the year. That makes them, other than the country music mecca of Nashville, the most heavily visited tourist destinations in the state, outpulling even the nearby Great Smoky Mountains National Park, which attracts nine million tourists a year.

headline.main: Pigeon Forge, Tenn., Attracts Tourists And Money, as Well as Traffic Jams
headline.kicker: Nature Is Second Fiddle To Dolly's Theme Park

docs.abstract: Many small towns across country, such as Pigeon Forge, Tenn, home of Dollywood, Dolly Parton's flower-laden theme park, have used local attractions to turn themselves into major tourist destinations; Pigeon Forge has developed tourism department that has contributed to town's success in taking in $545 million last year; nearby Gatlinburg pulled in nearly $307 million, also a record; there is transient quality to life in Pigeon Forge; many of thousands of new jobs are low paying and hard to fill; town officials acknowledge town's social problems; other small towns that have become major tourist destinations include Bar Harbor, Me, Branson, Mo, Eureka Springs, Ark, Jackson, Wyo, Sedona, Ariz, and Solvang, Calif; chart; map; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Medical Association has proudly announced that it will charge the Sunbeam Corporation potentially lucrative royalties in exchange for endorsing some of the company's products. The association, which is the nation's largest organization of physicians, defends its appalling decision by declaring that the alliance will provide consumers ''valuable health information that will help them live healthier lives.'' Here is a better way to achieve the same noble purpose. The association would endorse effective health products, Sunbeam's or any other company's. But it would do so without trying to make money. That way, consumers will know that their doctors are pushing products that are best for the patient's health, not best for the financial health of the association.
docs.abstract: Editorial scores American Medical Association's accord to endorse Sunbeam Corp products; sees conflict of interest (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: White House officials said today that they were studying a plan to restore about half of the $200 million that New York State would lose because of President Clinton's veto on Monday of a provision assuring the state greater access to Federal Medicaid funds. Chris Jennings, Mr. Clinton's health-policy adviser, said the Administration was examining whether it could act on its own, without legislation by Congress, to grant New York a partial waiver from a 1991 law at the center of a long dispute between the Federal Government and the state over Medicaid money.

headline.main: White House Again Signals Compromise On Medicaid

docs.abstract: White House officials are studying plan to restore about half of $200 million that New York State would lose because of Pres Clinton's veto of provision assuring state greater access to Medicaid funds; Chris Jennings, Clinton's health-policy adviser, says Administration is examining whether it can act without legislation by Congress to grant New York partial waiver from 1991 law at center of dispute between Federal Government and state over Medicaid money (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton will order changes in the testing of prescription drugs to insure that manufacturers specifically examine the drugs' effects on children if the medications are to be used by any significant number of young patients, White House officials said today. The officials said they decided to require such studies because drug companies were not doing enough pediatric studies on their own.

headline.main: President to Order Drug Makers to Conduct Pediatric Studies

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton plans to order Food and Drug Administration to require prescription drug makers to test on children drugs to be used by significant number of children; Clinton Administration aides say drug companies are not doing enough pediatric studies on own; trade group cites difficulty of recruiting children for studies (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Advisers to President Clinton said today that the White House was prepared to open negotiations with the Pataki administration to resolve a dispute that had jeopardized the payment of hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal Medicaid money to the state. The three-year-old argument came to the forefront on Monday when the President used his new line item veto powers to delete a Federal budget provision intended to preserve rules that have allowed New York State to collect up to $2.6 billion in Federal Medicaid matching funds since 1992.

headline.main: White House Talks Likely With Albany on Medicaid

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton's advisers say that White House is prepared to open negotiations with Pataki administration to resolve dispute that has jeopardized payment of hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal Medicaid money to state; Pres Clinton on Aug 11 used his new line item veto powers to delete Federal budget provision intended to preserve rules that have allowed New York State to collect up to $2.6 billion in Medicaid matching funds since 1992; Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani says that if Clinton does not reverse his action, city will bring lawsuit challenging constitutionality of line item veto (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A 73-YEAR-OLD Memphis woman was discharged from the hospital with a prescription for medication that was not covered by her Medicare managed-care health plan. Because she could not afford to pay for it herself, she did without it, suffered a relapse and had to be readmitted to the hospital, where she was able to get the drug she needed. A Maryland woman in her early 50's seemed to break a bone every time she bumped into something. After the third fracture, she asked the primary care doctor in her managed-care plan what might be causing her bones to break. The doctor said she was clumsy and did nothing further. Not until the sixth fracture, a broken toe that resulted from kicking a foam-rubber ball, was she given a bone density test, which revealed advanced osteoporosis.
docs.abstract: Jane Brody's Personal Health column examining how older women fare under managed-care health plans; finds while managed care offers important advantages over fee-for-service in areas of prevention and early detection, it often limits access to specialists and reduces treatment options, especially for older women who live longer and suffer more chronic ills than men (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York's Governor, George Pataki, has the unenviable job of winnowing through 374 newly passed pieces of legislation. Thanks to the chaos of the Albany political process, some are bound to be flawed due to accidental drafting errors. But the lawmakers also passed some very bad bills on purpose, opting to please special interests at the expense of the state's welfare. It is left to Mr. Pataki to show his leadership and veto them. Unfortunately, there are signs that the Governor may follow the legislators' irresponsible lead and sign a bill requiring health plans in the state to cover nearly unlimited chiropractic services. This is classic special-interest legislation that would never have seen the light of day had it not been for aggressive lobbying by chiropractors eager for a boost in their business. There is no broad medical reason for the bill, since people will always be able to buy policies that include the service. But forcing every individual and employer to purchase that coverage will raise premiums and discourage employers from providing health policies at all. Mr. Pataki still has time to change his mind and save New York from this truly inexcusable boondoggle.
docs.abstract: Editorial, scoring New York State Legislature for approving special-interest bills, urges Gov George Pataki to veto bills requiring health plans to provide nearly unlimited chiropractic services and transferring power to discipline New York City police officers to outside hearing officers; urges him to swiftly veto pension sweetener for New York City teachers; scores him for signing bill creating special public school district for Kiryas Joel, Hasidic Jewish community whose residents tend to vote as bloc (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today became the first chief executive in the nation's history to use the Federal line item veto, striking down two narrow tax breaks and a provision that had been specifically designed to help New York State reap more Federal Medicaid money. Mr. Clinton's decision to eliminate the three measures from the recently signed balanced budget and tax-cut laws marked the first use of a power that Presidents have sought for more than a century. Granted, albeit reluctantly, by the Republican-controlled Congress last year, it allows the President to kill individual items in broad tax and spending bills.

headline.main: President Makes First Use of New Veto

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton becomes first chief executive in nation's history to use Federal line item veto sought by Presidents for more than century, striking down two narrow tax breaks and provision specifically designed to help New York State reap more Federal Medicaid money; Medicaid provision would have allowed New York to continue levying several categories of taxes on health-care providers that has been questioned by Health and Human Services Department under 1991 law designed to keep states from overcollecting Federal Medicaid dollars; Clinton says no other state has been allowed provision, and that it would unfair for taxpayers to subsidize it; New York Congressional delegation and Gov George Pataki denounce veto; Pataki vows to do everything in power to overturn it; Clinton also vetoes provision giving tax deferral on sale of certain food processing plants to farmers' cooperatives, as well as provision allowing financial service companies to defer payment of taxes on income from overseas operations; seen facing constitutional challenges, despite show of confidence, over whether line item veto improperly shifts power over spending and taxes from Congress to President; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the United Parcel Service strike misstated the benefits policy of Federal Express. Part-time workers there become eligible for company-paid health insurance after 90 days on the job.

docs.lead_paragraph: In his inaugural use of the line item veto, President Clinton today erased a budget provision inserted at the behest of Gov. George E. Pataki to help New York State finance health care for the poor. State officials said the President's action would create new financial strains on the decades-old system. The provision would have preserved a system of state taxes that has generated more than $5 billion in revenues since 1992 and helped finance several major health-care programs, including hospital services for the indigent and health insurance for low-income children.

headline.main: New York Stripped of Tax Setup That Aided Health-Care Services

docs.abstract: New York State officials say Pres Clinton's use of line-item veto to erase budget provision, offered by Sen Alfonse D'Amato at behest of Gov George E Pataki to help state pay for health care for poor, will create new financial strains on decades-old system; provision would have preserved system of state taxes that has generated more than $5 billion in revenues since 1992 and helped finance several major health-care programs; Clinton says provision would have given New York special treatment that other states do not have but might covet, exempting it from 1991 law designed to prevent states from overcollecting Federal Medicaid dollars; says no other state in nation would have provision and that it is unfair to ask rest of nation's taxpayers to subsidize it (M)
